questions.question: Which nerve will be involved in the following finding on rest?
questions.explanation: characterized by: Hyperextension at the MCP joints Flexion at the PIP and DIP joints More pronounced in the 4th and 5th fingers Deformities in ulnar nerve injury: Partial claw hand: Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints. Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only. Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury . Also known as the true claw hand. Complete claw hand: Clawing of all 4 fingers. Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy. Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture. Other deformities: Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand. Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand. Ulnar paradox: The higher the lesion, the less severe the deformity. Reason: Long finger flexors are paralyzed and loss of finger flexion makes the deformity less obvious. Treatment of Ulnar claw hand: Static procedure (removal) Zancolli

questions.question: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Radial nerve Explanation: Image displayed is Dynamic Cock-up wrist splint used in management of Radial nerve palsy causing Wrist drop. Radial nerve management: Type of Injury Treatment Open Injuries Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting Closed Injuries Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting Fractures of Humerus Assess for nerve injury on admission If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately Recovery Management Perform passive hand movements Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint: Long-term Disability Tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor Incorrect options: Median nerve (Option B): Median nerve injury can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome . Rest + Analgesics are the preferred management. Ulnar nerve (Option C): Knuckle bender splint is used in the management of ulnar nerve injury. Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option D): Volkman splint or Turn buckle splint is used in the management.

questions.question: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Carpal tunnel syndrome, Durkan's test Explanation: Tingling and numbness of fingers, with symptoms worsening at night is suggestive of Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) . The most reliable clinical test to diagnose CTS is the Durkan test . Carpal tunnel syndrome: Definition Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist Symptoms Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers Pain in hand and wrist, Weakness in grip Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day. Advanced cases may lead to hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy. Structures Affected Median Nerve : Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs. Flexor Tendons : The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve. Structures Spared Thenar Eminence : Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel. Clinical Signs Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition. Atrophy : Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases. Sensory Loss : Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit). Causes Idiopathic- commonest cause Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly Diagnostic Tests Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test Electromyography (EMG) Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms. Durkan test: Direct compression on Median nerve for 30 seconds. More specific than the Phalen/Tinel test. Treatment Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification Corticosteroid injections Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases) Guyon’s canal syndrome and Froment’s test (Option A): Refers to involvement of the Ulnar side of the wrist leading to compression of Ulnar nerve. Froment’s test: Used to test adductor pollicis muscle (supplied by Ulnar nerve).

questions.question: The type of splint shown in the image is known as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cock-up splint Explanation: Image displayed is Dynamic Cock-up wrist splint used in management of Radial nerve palsy causing Wrist drop. Radial nerve management: Type of Injury Treatment Open Injuries Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting Closed Injuries Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting Fractures of Humerus Assess for nerve injury on admission If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately Recovery Management Perform passive hand movements Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint: Long-term Disability Tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor Incorrect Options: Wrist splint (Option A): Wrist splints are widely used during post operative and post reduction period to reduce the pain and promote proper healing. The two conditions where a wrist splint is indicated are carpal tunnel syndrome and osteoarthritis (OA) . Knuckle bender splint (Option C): This splint is used to flex metacarpophalangeal (MCP) in cases of Ulnar nerve injury . Dynamic finger splint (Option D): This splint is spring loaded and is used to provide stretch to those joints with reduced range of motion due to immobilization. It is done mainly after tendon and ligament injury, surgical repair etc.

questions.question: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pointing index sign Explanation: The image in the question shows the Pointing Index sign seen in Median Nerve injury . Clinical tests for Median nerve: Test Muscle tested and action Pen test: Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis Action: Abduction of thumb Oschner clasp test: Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits Pointing index sign seen. Thumb opposition: Muscle: Opponens pollcis Action: Opposition of thumb O-sign is seen in normal patients Treatment of median nerve palsy: Conservative management mainly. If not recovered, nerve repair is done by High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months Incorrect Options: Froment’s sign (Option A) : This sign is used to test function of Adductor Pollicis muscle specifically used to test ulnar nerve palsy. The patient will be asked to hold a piece of paper in between thumb and index finger and the examiner will attempt to pull the paper from the patient's grip. Benediction sign (Option C): Patient when asked to make a fist, his/her middle and index fingers are extended. Hand of benediction (Preacher's hand) indicates clinical sign of peripheral neuropathy. It is specifically indicative of peripheral neuropathy affecting the muscles of the

questions.question: The patient experiences an inability to extend their wrist upon waking up after sleeping with their arm hanging over the back of a chair. This condition is caused by
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Neuropraxia Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Saturday night palsy, which is caused due to transient compression of radial nerve - known as Neuropraxia . The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components. Type Description Prognosis Neurapraxia (Grade I) Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only. No neuroma and no degeneration. Recovery is complete within 6 weeks. Axonotmesis (Grade II) Axonal damage, connective tissue intact. Neuroma in continuity. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Recovery can take up to months Complete recovery may not occur. Motor march present Neurotmesis (Grade III) Complete nerve disruption. End or side neuroma. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Spontaneous recovery never occurs. Repair is required (poor recovery) Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 281

questions.question: After a surgical procedure, the patient demonstrates a particular clinical sign. Which specific nerve is likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Median nerve Explanation: The image in the question shows the Pointing Index sign seen in Median Nerve injury . Clinical tests for Median nerve: Test Muscle tested and action Pen test: Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis Action: Abduction of thumb Oschner clasp test: Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits Pointing index sign seen. Thumb opposition: Muscle: Opponens pollcis Action: Opposition of thumb O-sign is seen in normal patients Treatment of median nerve palsy: Conservative management mainly. If not recovered, nerve repair is done by High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.question: What condition is caused by nerve injury?
questions.explanation: hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits due to the paralysis of the 3rd and 4th lubricants, which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Deformities in ulnar nerve injury: Partial claw hand: Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints. Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only. Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury . Also known as the true claw hand. Complete claw hand: Clawing of all 4 fingers. Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy. Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture. Other deformities: Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand. Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand. Ulnar paradox: The higher the lesion, the less severe the deformity. Reason: Long finger flexors are paralyzed and loss of finger flexion makes the deformity less obvious. Treatment of Ulnar claw hand: Static procedure (removal) Zancolli Lasso procedure Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer) Modified Bunnel technique Brand’s operation Fowler’s operation Radial Nerve (Option B) palsy causes wrist drop due to paralysis of the extensor carpi radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis. Compression of the radial nerve in the radial groove while putting a hand on a chair/clutch causes Saturday night/crutch palsy. Median Nerve (Option C) palsy causes carpal tunnel syndrome (Compression neuropathy).

questions.question: When the outer sheath and nerve fiber remain intact while the inner axons are affected, this condition is referred to as
questions.explanation: known as axonotmesis. Tinel’s sign is positive and progressive. It is an axonal breakdown. Recovery is not complete. An injury to the peripheral nerve of one of the extremities of the body. The axons and their myelin sheath are damaged, but the endoneurium, perineurium and epineurium remain intact is defined as axonotmesis. The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components. Type Description Prognosis Neurapraxia (Grade I) (Option A) Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only. No neuroma and no degeneration. Recovery is complete within 6 weeks. Axonotmesis (Grade II) (Option B) Axonal damage, connective tissue intact. Neuroma in continuity. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Recovery can take up to months Complete recovery may not occur. Motor march present Neurotmesis (Grade III) (Option D) Complete nerve disruption. End or side neuroma. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Spontaneous recovery never occurs. Repair is required (poor recovery) Axonopraxia (Option B) There is a partial axonal disruption with no significant damage to the surrounding nerve structure. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 281 Neurapraxia

questions.question: The following test is done to assess?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Median nerve Explanation: Image shows Pen test , done to test Abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is a test of Median nerve. Clinical tests for Median nerve: Test Muscle tested and action Pen test: Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C) Action: Abduction of thumb Oschner clasp test: Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits Pointing index sign seen. Thumb opposition: Muscle: Opponens pollcis Action: Opposition of thumb O-sign is seen in normal patients Treatment of median nerve palsy: Conservative management mainly. If not recovered, nerve repair is done by High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is the name of this test?
questions.explanation: evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). TOS is a condition characterized by the compression or irritation of the neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet, which can lead to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness in the upper extremities. During the Roos test, the patient is asked to actively elevate both arms to 90 degrees, flex the elbows to 90 degrees, and open and close their hands for approximately three minutes. If the patient experiences symptoms, such as numbness, tingling, or the inability to maintain the position due to pain or weakness, it may indicate a positive Roos test, suggesting the presence of TOS. Incorrect Options: Option A - Adson's Test: Adson's test is another test used to evaluate TOS. It involves checking the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck. This test is not demonstrated in the scenario. Option B - Pemberton Test: The Pemberton test is used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome caused by the compression of structures between the clavicle and the first rib. It involves raising both arms above the head (180 degrees anterior flexion at the shoulder) while monitoring for symptoms. Unlike the Roos test, it does not involve pumping the fists. Option D - Wright Test: The Wright test, also known as the Hyperabduction Test, is a clinical examination used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
